status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment: Does this happen with just a single oak instance running or does this happen when you run it concurrently?

Somehow the base state field of KernelNodeBuilder and its base class MemoryNodeBuilder are not in sync.

I'm not too familiar with the logic there. AFAIU the base state may be outdated and there is a check in place to detect it. Looking at the various implementations this check is not always done the same way:

  • MemoryNodeBuilder.getBaseState() delegates to base(), which uses the baseRevision on the root builder and compares it to a copy of the revision on this builder when it last re-fetched the base state from the parent.
  • KernelNodeBuilder.getBaseState() overwrites the method on MemoryNodeBuilder and keeps a cached copy of the base node state. This was recently introduced with OAK-1142. Should this also update the base state field on the MemoryNodeBuilder?
  • MongoNodeBuilder.getBaseState() overwrites the method on memoryNodeBuilder but does not perform the additional check of the root builder. Once the base field is initialized getBaseState() will not re-fetch it. To me it looks like this is also not quite correct.

I'm able to run the test successfully when I change the MemoryNodeBuilder like this:

--- src/main/java/org/apache/jackrabbit/oak/plugins/memory/MemoryNodeBuilder.java	(revision 1551509)
+++ src/main/java/org/apache/jackrabbit/oak/plugins/memory/MemoryNodeBuilder.java	(revision )
@@ -128,8 +128,8 @@
         this.parent = parent;
         this.name = name;
         this.rootBuilder = parent.rootBuilder;
+        this.base = parent.base().getChildNode(name);
         this.baseRevision = parent.baseRevision;
-        this.base = parent.base.getChildNode(name);
         this.head = new UnconnectedHead();
     }

MongoNodeBuilder.getBaseState() overwrites the method on memoryNodeBuilder but

This seems to be wrong and we should add the same logic like in the KernelNodeBuilder case.
In fact this seems to be the cause of the failure seen in my patch for OAK-1232.

mduerig also pointed out that the base fields for KernelNodeBuilder and MemoryNodeBuilder may indeed be different because the base node state of a KernelNodeBuilder is always the state at the point when changes started, whereas the base state of MemoryNodeBuilder may be set to the persisted branch state.
Committed patch in http://svn.apache.org/r1551591
